title: Nucleus, Chromatin and Ribosomes
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Detailed exploration of DNA organisation from double helix to chromatin to chromosomes, nucleolus function, and the structural differences between 70S and 80S ribosomes.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the levels of DNA organisation from DNA double helix to chromatin to chromosomes.
Students can explain the function of the nucleolus in ribosome production.
Students can distinguish between 70S and 80S ribosomes in terms of location and antibiotic sensitivity.

engagementHook.title: The Ribosome Factory
engagementHook.content: 'If a cell needs to make thousands of proteins per second, it needs thousands of ribosomes. Where are these protein-making machines manufactured? In the nucleolus—a factory inside the nucleus that exports ribosome parts 24/7. When cells are very active (like cancer cells), the nucleolus is large and dark. When cells are quiet, it's small.'

keyConcepts.definition: DNA wrapped around histone proteins forming nucleosomes ('beads on a string'). Allows long DNA (2m) to fit in nucleus (6 µm). Condenses into visible chromosomes during cell division.
Dark staining region in nucleus where ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is made and combined with proteins to form ribosomal subunits (40S and 60S). Not membrane-bound.
Subunits made in nucleolus → exported through nuclear pores to cytoplasm → assemble into 80S ribosomes when protein synthesis begins.
70S: In prokaryotes (and mitochondria/chloroplasts). Target of antibiotics. 80S: In eukaryotic cytoplasm. Not affected by antibiotics targeting 70S.

misconceptions.misconception: The nucleolus is a separate organelle
misconceptions.correction: It's a region within the nucleus, not a separate membrane-bound structure.

misconceptions.misconception: Ribosomes are only made in the cytoplasm
misconceptions.correction: Subunits made in nucleolus, assembled in cytoplasm.

misconceptions.misconception: All ribosomes in human cells are 80S

multipleChoice.question: The nucleolus is responsible for:
options: Producing ribosomal RNA and assembling ribosome subunits
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Producing ribosomal RNA and assembling ribosome subunits
multipleChoice.rationale: Core nucleolus function. DNA is stored as chromatin; pores control entry/exit; Golgi packages proteins.

multipleChoice.question: Eukaryotic ribosomes (80S) differ from prokaryotic ribosomes (70S) in that they:
options: Are found only in the nucleus
Are not affected by antibiotics that target bacterial ribosomes
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Are not affected by antibiotics that target bacterial ribosomes
multipleChoice.rationale: Reinforces antibiotic selectivity from L1-L2. 80S ribosomes are larger, found in cytoplasm, and contain rRNA.

multipleChoice.question: DNA is packaged with proteins called histones to form:
multipleChoice.rationale: Chromatin is the DNA-protein complex. Chromosomes are condensed chromatin during division; nucleolus makes ribosomes.

shortAnswer.question: Outline the role of the nucleolus in producing ribosomes. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Site of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) synthesis/production
1 mark: Assembly of ribosomal subunits (40S and 60S) which are then exported to the cytoplasm
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying 'protein synthesis happens here' (confusing with cytoplasmic ribosomes).

shortAnswer.question: Explain why antibiotics that stop protein synthesis in bacteria do not stop protein synthesis in human cells. (2 marks)

definitions: DNA is wrapped around histone proteins to form chromatin.
The nucleolus makes ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and assembles ribosome subunits.
Ribosome subunits leave the nucleus through nuclear pores.
Bacterial ribosomes are 70S—these are targeted by antibiotics.
keyPoints: Nucleosomes = DNA wrapped around histone proteins ('beads on a string')
Chromatin condenses to form chromosomes during cell division
Nucleolus = dark region, NOT membrane-bound, makes rRNA
diagrams: DNA packaging diagram: double helix → nucleosome → chromatin
Nucleolus showing subunit export through nuclear pores

shortAnswer: The nucleolus is the site of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) synthesis. It assembles ribosomal subunits (40S and 60S) by combining rRNA with proteins imported from the cytoplasm. These subunits are then exported through nuclear pores to the cytoplasm where they assemble into functional 80S ribosomes.

Bacteria have 70S ribosomes which have a different structure from the 80S ribosomes in human cells. Antibiotics such as tetracycline can bind specifically to the 70S ribosomes and block protein synthesis in bacteria, but they cannot bind effectively to the larger 80S ribosomes in human cells. This structural difference means human protein synthesis is not affected.
